Class SearchEngine

java.lang.Object
  SearchEngine

public class SearchEngine
extends java.lang.Object

A class for performing all of the required search operations for the Phonetic Search algorithm.

Version:
1.0
Author:
Curtis Kennington

Constructor Detail

SearchEngine

SearchEngine(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> names)
Constructor method for SearchEngine. This is initialised with an ArrayList of names which will is pre-processed using #processInput(java.util.ArrayList) and preprocessName(String).

Parameters:
names - An ArrayList a collection of names which will form the basis of a library used in all search requests.
Method Detail

processInput

private void processInput(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> names)
A private method which takes all of the names and instantiates it as a Name object. This method also performs the pre-processing tasks (Steps 1 - 3) as outlined in the algorithm using the preprocessName(String) and stores the result in the created Name object. This Name object is then added to the "library" ArrayList.

Parameters:
names - A collection of names which will form the basis of a library used in all search requests.

preprocessName

private java.lang.String preprocessName(java.lang.String original)
Performs the pre-processing operations on the provided name string as per steps 1-3 in the algorithm:

STEP 1: Filter out non-alphabetical characters using a regular expression.
STEP 2: Convert all characters to upper-case to facilitate case-insensitivity.
STEP 3: Remove all instances of A,E,I,H,O,U,W,Y after the first letter using a regular expression.

Parameters:
original - The original name string to be pre-processed.
Returns:
The pre-processed string.

search

public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> search(java.lang.String term)
Performs the Phonetic Search algorithm on the provided term. This method will first of all convert the search term into a Name object and pre-process it. It then applies the second part of the search algorithm on each name in the library individually (the first half has already been applied via pre-processing - see preprocessName(String)). The second part of the algorithm is implemented in compare(Name, Name).

Parameters:
term - The name to find a match for.
Returns:
An ArrayList containing matches (if any).

compare

private boolean compare(Name n1,
                        Name n2)
Compares 2 names against eachother using steps 4-5 of the algorithm. If the 2 names match true will be returned. False will indicate an invalid match.

STEP 4: Identify the equivalent characters. A match is verified using getCharacterGroup(char) within a for loop checking a character array of both names. If a match is found, the function continues onto step 5. Otherwise false is returned.
STEP 5: Identify any consecutive occurrences of equivalent letters and consider them as a single occurance. This is done by iterating through the remainder of both word character arrays in conjunction with getCharacterGroup(char). If a match is found, the array index is increased meaning it will be skipped in the next iteration of the for loop.

The method finishes by checking the number of characters compared for each name to ensure it matches the length of the original name. If this fails, we assume there is extra character(s) in the name, and return false to indicate a failed comparison. If all of these checks are passed, we have a match and true is returned.

Parameters:
n1 - A word to be compared to another.
n2 - A word to be compared to another.
Returns:
True to indicate a successful comparison. Failed matchings will return false.

getCharacterGroup

private int getCharacterGroup(char c)
A simple function which matches the character in the parameter to its matching HashSet. If it matches a set, an integer between 1-8 will be returned, indicating the set it belongs to. If a match cannot be found -1 will be returned.

Parameters:
c - The character to be matched to a group.
Returns:
An integer between 1-8 for successful matchings. -1 if no matching set can be found.
